did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: 1694-2002 (bulk 1880-1930). The Fred Rochlin Papers contain material relating to his research on the southwestern Jewish community. The collection includes material relevant to the history of Jewish individuals, commercial operations, and communal institutions in Arizona, principally southern Arizona.

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Fred Rochlin papers (MS 401). University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Fred Rochlin was born in 1923 in a house on a twenty-acre site three miles east of Nogales, on the Arizona-Sonora border. His parents, Annie (Shapiro) and Jake Rochlin, Russian Jewish immigrants settled in Nogales in 1917. Fred, the youngest of their five children, graduated from Nogales High School and briefly attended the University of Arizona, Tucson. In December, 1942, he enlisted in the U.S. Army Air Corps, and was stationed in Italy with 456th Bombardment Group. With 14 citations, he was the 5th most decorated flying officer from Arizona.

Fred enrolled in the University of California at Berkeley, and graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in Architecture in January 1949. While on campus, Fred met and married Harriet Shapiro, a UC Berkeley graduate in Hispanic America. They have four children and three grandchildren.

Following graduation in 1949, Rochlin apprenticed in the offices of two renowned architects: Frank Lloyd Wright and Charles Eames. In 1952, he partnered with Berkeley classmate, Ephraim Baran, to form Rochlin & Baran, Architects, Engineers and Planning. During his tenure as founding partner, 1952 to 1986, the firm completed major medical facilities and observatories in California, seventeen other states, and in Iran and Israel.

While professionally engaged, in his spare time he conducted a passionate search for data and images documenting the history of early Jews in the Southwest, with special emphasis on southern Arizona and Arizona-Sonora border. He was also active in historical societies: American Jewish Historical Society, board member; Los Angeles Historical Society, board member; Southern California Jewish Historical Society, president; Southern Arizona Jewish Historical Society, founding member, Pimeria Alta Historical Society, member.
Harriet and Fred Rochlin. Pioneer Jews: A New Life in the Far West. (social history) Houghton Mifflin, Boston, 1984. 11 printings.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: This Collection is organized into eight series. Five series contain subseries: Biographical Files, Research Files, Photograph Files, Postcards, and Ephemera.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Papers, 1694-2002 (bulk 1880-1930). The Fred Rochlin Papers contain material relating to his research on the southwestern Jewish community. The collection includes material relevant to the history of Jewish individuals, commercial operations, and communal institutions in Arizona, principally southern Arizona.

This collection primarily consists of autobiographical reminiscences, copies of historical records, correspondence, newspaper clippings, interview transcriptions and notes, photographs and postcards, and scholarly and popular articles and excerpts. The bulk of the material is photocopies of primary source material. Please note that dates listed reflect the subject content of the material.

item.geogname: Mexican-American border region -- History -- Pictorial works

item.corpname: United States. Army. Air Corps -- Bombardment Groups, 456th -- History

scopecontent.p: Biographical Files is divided into four subseries. Subseries: Family (1950-2001) contains material regarding the personal lives, correspondence, and genealogies of Fred Rochlin and his immediate family. Subseries: General (1945-2002) contains correspondence with non-family, publications by the Rochlins, and high school reunion material. Subseries: Military (1942-2002) contains correspondence between Fred Rochlin and his family during his service in WWII, correspondence regarding the 456th Bomb Group, and official government documents relating to the service of Fred Rochlin. Subseries: Schedrin (1952-2002) contains personal correspondence and research material related to the Russian community of Schedrin, of particular interest to Fred Rochlin.

did.unittitle: Correspondence- Berkeley School of Architecture Reunion. 2001

scopecontent.p: Contains personal correspondence and research material related to the Russian community of Schedrin, Belarus, Fred's mother's birthplace and hometown.
Speech Files (1972-1988) Speeches given by Fred Rochlin on the subject of his research into the Jewish Communities of the Southwest. Includes speeches, notes and related research material.

did.unittitle: Los Angeles, Southern California Jewish Historical Society. 1968
New York City, American Jewish Historical Society. 1995
San Francisco, American Jewish Historical Conference. 1995

scopecontent.p: Jewish History Compilation Notebooks (1840-1999) include notebooks compiled by Fred Rochlin containing his personal notes and other material relating to the Jewish presence in Arizona from the earliest settlements in the mid 19th century to the late 20th century.

unittitle.title: Guide to References of Jewish Experience and Presence in Santa Cruz Co., Arizona.

scopecontent.p: Research Files (1694-2001) contains eleven subseries. They contain newspaper clippings, census records, publications, interviews, articles, and biographical accounts of Jewish individuals, families, businesses and communities. They are divided by geographic area. Subseries: Alaska (1868-1961) Subseries: Arizona (1694-2001) Subseries: California (1807-1994) Subseries: Colorado (1980-1988) Subseries: General (1882-2001) Subseries: Mexico (1849-1989), Subseries: New Mexico (1810-1992), Subseries: Photographic Research (1868-1991), Subseries: Texas (1813-1994), Subseries: Washington (1858-1995), Subseries: West (1808-1987).

scopecontent.p: Photograph Files contain nine subseries. Subseries: Borderlands (1890-1960) contains images of the border region of Arizona and Mexico. Subseries: Copy Prints (1860-1986) contain images of individuals and places in the Southwest. Subseries: Military (1940-1986) contains images of WWII military personnel, equipment, engagement, reunions, and Fred Rochlin during his term of service. Subseries: Miscellaneous Arizona and the Southwest (1880-1945) contains images of people and places throughout the West. Subseries: Nogales (1850-1970) contains images of individuals, places and events in Nogales, AZ. Subseries: Western Jews (1875-1950) contains images of early Jewish pioneers in the West. Subseries: Exhibit Photographs (1868-1929) contains matted images of Jewish individuals, families, and businesses in the southwest. Subseries: Oversize Photographs (1868-1945) contains images of various people and places. Subseries: Panoramas (1916) contains panoramic photographs of the army and their camps during the Mexican Punitive Expedition.

scopecontent.p: Oral Histories contains interviews of Jewish individuals and families.

Postcards contains two subseries. Subseries 1: Michael Rochlin Postcard Collection (1900-1985) includes images of various locations throughout the Southwest, principally Nogales Arizona and Mexico. Subseries 2: General Postcards and Postmarks (1900-1930) includes images from around the United States.

scopecontent.p: Ephemera contains twelve subseries. Includes publications, pamphlets, maps, and ledgers divided by region.
